skill.name: command-management
skill.description: Create and manage custom slash commands for Claude Code following template standards and best practices
skill.summary: Create and manage custom slash commands for Claude Code following template standards
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation and template skill with no executable code. Static analysis flagged 147 potential issues in documentation files (command examples, template placeholders, bash execution syntax). All findings are FALSE POSITIVES - the analyzer misidentified documentation examples and template syntax as security patterns. This skill only contains markdown documentation files that define command templates and usage guidelines.

content.value_statement: Developers spend time recreating common prompts and workflows. This skill provides templates and guidance for creating reusable slash commands in Claude Code, reducing repetitive work and standardizing team workflows.
actual_capabilities: Create personal slash commands available across all projects in ~/.claude/commands/
Follow standardized template with YAML frontmatter and workflow sections
Test created commands using the SlashCommand tool
Organize commands using namespacing and subdirectories
Configure allowed tools and permissions for each command
limitations: Does not execute actual bash commands - only creates command files
Commands are limited to Claude Code environment
Does not provide command implementation logic

use_cases.title: Team workflow standardization
use_cases.description: Create consistent commands for common team workflows like code review, commit messages, or testing procedures. All team members use the same prompts with standardized outputs.

use_cases.title: Personal productivity automation
use_cases.description: Build personal commands for frequently used tasks like generating boilerplate code, running diagnostics, or creating documentation templates across any project.

use_cases.title: Onboarding and documentation
use_cases.description: Create commands that guide new team members through setup procedures, coding standards reviews, or deployment processes with consistent step-by-step instructions.

best_practices: Keep command descriptions concise and action-oriented
Use the YAML frontmatter to define allowed tools explicitly for security
Test commands with the SlashCommand tool before deployment
anti_patterns: Avoid creating commands without proper YAML frontmatter
Do not save commands outside the .claude/commands/ or ~/.claude/commands/ directories
Avoid granting excessive tool permissions - use least-privilege principle

faq.question: Where are custom slash commands stored?
faq.answer: Project commands go in .claude/commands/ within your repository. Personal commands go in ~/.claude/commands/ in your home directory and are available across all projects.

faq.question: How do I test a newly created command?
faq.answer: Use the SlashCommand tool with the command name. For example, run /SlashCommand name="/your-command" to test. You can also trigger it naturally by referencing the command in conversation.

faq.question: Can I use arguments in slash commands?
faq.answer: Yes. Use $ARGUMENTS for all arguments or $1, $2, etc. for individual positional parameters. Define argument hints in the frontmatter for user guidance.

faq.question: How do I restrict which tools a command can use?
faq.answer: Add the allowed-tools field in the YAML frontmatter. List specific tools with optional wildcards like Bash(git add:*). This follows the principle of least privilege.

faq.question: What happens if I create a command with the same name as a built-in command?
faq.answer: Custom commands cannot override built-in slash commands. Use unique names for your custom commands to avoid conflicts.

faq.question: Can I organize commands into categories?
faq.answer: Yes. Create subdirectories within .claude/commands/ for organization. The subdirectory name appears in the command description but does not affect the command name.
